nodes.title: Tennessee's new political maps approved by Republicans dismembered Nashvilleâ€™s solidly blue House district â€” held by a Democrat for 147 years â€” and scattered its remains among three new districts that stretch deep into Republican rural areas. https://t.co/22YcAlzsIt
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: The Omicron wave is slowing, but the number of people who have died during it has surpassed the number from the Delta wave â€” and it's still increasing in much of the U.S. Since Nov. 24, the country has confirmed more than 154,750 new deaths. https://t.co/XWqvAXIxTE
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title: Jean-Luc Brunel, a former French modeling agent who had been charged with the rape of minors and was suspected of scouting young women for Jeffrey Epstein, was found dead in his Paris jail cell, officials said on Saturday, in what appeared to be a suicide. https://t.co/718jhSHflr
nodes.author: The New York Times

nodes.title:
About 10% to 30% of people infected with the coronavirus may develop long-term symptoms, studies estimate. And four factors appear to increase the risk.

Here's what we know about how long Covid takes inside the body â€” and why it can be so debilitating. https://t.co/5ZHYg9604w

nodes.title:

nodes.title: Ottawa police moved in to arrest protesters on Friday, with at least 15 people arrested as of midday. Tow trucks whose license plates had been removed and company names covered with Ottawa police stickers were beginning to tow protestersâ€™ trucks away. https://t.co/hAu4zRQPVQ

nodes.title: Watching 15-year-old Kamila Valieva and her 17-year-old teammates suffer on TV after the free skate on Thursday has prompted some to ask if raising the minimum competition age at the Olympics would help protect young athletes from abuse and humiliation. https://t.co/X9LqRtHYZH

nodes.title: A federal judge ruled that three civil lawsuits against Donald Trump over the Capitol attack can proceed, denying the former president's claims of immunity. https://t.co/L8Wd6uM6Ri

nodes.title: Breaking News: The U.S. has intelligence that President Vladimir Putin has decided to invade Ukraine and target the capital Kyiv, President Biden said. https://t.co/ugjStlEgVh

nodes.title: During the Berlin airlift of 1948, Lt. Gail Halvorsen helped drop 23 tons of candies, chocolate and chewing gum wrapped in tiny parachutes to the children of West Berlin. He became known as the â€œCandy Bomber.â€ He died this week at 101. https://t.co/ykfKFmSXQl

nodes.title:
Hundreds of police moved in to arrest protesters in Ottawa on Friday, hoping to end weeks of gridlock. Anticipation grew as demonstrators heard reports of police cruisers amassing nearby. â€œTheyâ€™re going to corral us,â€ one man said.

Read the latest. https://t.co/Hi2cgG2eB6 https://t.co/ym28EAY89u

A Marine Corps reservist who was charged with entering the U.S. Capitol during the Jan. 6 riot is now accused of conspiring with a nurse to steal, forge and distribute hundreds of fake Covid vaccination cards, prosecutors said.
https://t.co/jc9Qq1tjcZ

nodes.title: An anime convention held in Manhattan last November was not a superspreader event, a new CDC study found. Good air filtration, widespread vaccination and masks indoors prevented the 53,000-person event from causing a major Covid outbreak, the agency said. https://t.co/IT2ZIZVXgk

nodes.title: An Omicron subvariant that scientists believe is even more contagious is on the rise, the WHO said. It has become dominant in several Asian countries, but a decline in coronavirus testing is muddling the global picture. https://t.co/2UXsrBT3m1

nodes.title: Breaking News: Spotify lured Joe Rogan with a $200 million deal, double initial reports. It made the company a podcasting giant. But controversy followed, putting the company at the center of a fiery debate about misinformation and free speech. https://t.co/gOsaKRKYmr
